title: Airbus Ruling Will Push Imported Wine and Cheese Prices Higher
text:
Text size

The U.S.’s trade dispute with the European Union over subsidies to the Netherlands-based Airbus is about to make the cost of French wine and cheese, single-malt Scotch, and Irish Whiskey—among a slew of other products—skyrocket.

The steep tariffs on US$7.5 billion of European and U.K. goods are in response to a World Trade Organization ruling in favor of the U.S., which had challenged European aircraft subsidies to Airbus in a long-running dispute.

Levies of 10% will be applied to large aircraft exports while levies of 25% will be slapped on a number of European and U.K. products, although some—including brandies and non-alcoholic beer—were spared in the final list produced by the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) on Wednesday.

Relieving some products from tariffs in the final ruling was a “little bit of a silver lining, but in a fight over aircraft, it seems ridiculous to penalize beverage alcohol,” says Robert Tobiassen, president of the National Association of Beverage Importers (NABI).

Airbus has U.S. operations, and as a result, imports parts to the U.S. “If they have an unfair advantage, impose tariffs on parts they are bringing into the U.S.—don’t go after cheese, olives, and wine,” Tobiassen says. “Don’t make consumers collateral damage in what is a trade war on civil aircraft.”

The USTR had threatened tariffs as high as 100%, so in some ways, 25% tariffs are a relief. But Philip Marfuggi, president of the Cheese Importers Association of America, says it still doesn’t make sense for the U.S. to impose tariffs of only 10% on aircraft—and not include aircraft parts—and 25% tariffs on agricultural products.

“You want to negotiate an agriculture deal, negotiate that, but don’t use it as a bargaining chip in an airline dispute,” says Marfuggi, who is also president and CEO of the Ambriola Co., a New Jersey importer largely of Italian cheeses. “To see that 10% [tariff on aircraft] and cheese, 25%—that’s difficult to comprehend.”

The levies will go into effect Oct. 18 if approved by the WTO on Oct. 14, according to a Wednesday news release from the USTR.

A wide range of imports to the U.S. stand to be affected, with most applied to products from France, Germany, Spain, and the U.K., which the USTR office said in the release are the “four countries responsible for the illegal subsidies” for Airbus.

But the final list appears to create a hodge-podge application of tariffs that is likely to create significant market disparities between similar products on grocery and liquor-store shelves. The tariffs hit French still wine, for instance, but sparkling wine, including Champagne, from throughout Europe and the U.K. is spared. And while Spanish Rioja, German Riesling, and French Burgundy will all get pricier, wine from Italy or Austria won’t feel the pinch.

Similarly, olive oil from Italy won’t see tariffs, but olive oil from Spain will.

The impact to the market share of these products could lead to infighting among EU member states, Tobiassen says.

Pricier Cheese

The European cheese industry was hit particularly hard, with 80% of cheese coming out of Europe being affected, Marfuggi says.

That figure represents US$1 billion in imported cheese, which turns into about US$3.5 billion in revenue for U.S. companies and workers, he says. The tariffs will hit truckers, supermarket workers, and factory workers who convert bulk cheese into supermarket-ready products.

“We’re looking at probably 20,000 jobs in our industry [that] could be affected by these tariffs,” Marfuggi says, noting that the 25% tariffs will be additional to existing tariffs that average about 12% to 15% on all cheese imports.

What that will mean on grocery shelves is that a cheese costing US$15.99 a pound today will be US$24.99 a pound, while eight ounces of grated Parmesan will go from US$7.99 to US$13.99, he says.

“It’s going to slow sales down considerably,” Marfuggi says.

Similarly, the beverage industry estimates there is significant potential damage to the approximately 12,000 beverage importers in the U.S. and the people who work for them.

These importers “bring in brand names that are not necessarily well known across the country, but they’ve developed a niche market” for them, Tobiassen says. “They can’t absorb tariffs the way large companies can.”

In a news release, the Distilled Spirits Council says the tariffs on Scotch, liqueurs and cordials, and wine, could impact nearly US$3.4 billion in imports, and lead to the loss of 13,000 jobs in the U.S.

According to a group of beverage trade groups, a 25% tariff on American whiskey imposed by the EU last summer in response to U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum imports has led to a 19% dive in exports. China has imposed a 54% retaliatory tariff on U.S. wine imports, which the trade groups say has caused a 57% nosedive in China trade this year.

The Wine Institute in the U.S. said on Thursday that it’s concerned the new U.S. tariffs will lead to further retaliatory action by the EU and U.K., with tariffs subsequently slapped on wine exported from California. U.S. wine exports to the EU had reached US$469 million as of last year, representing the U.S.’s largest wine export market.

Previously, the EU said it would impose tariffs on U.S. wine, vodka, and rum should the U.S. tariffs be imposed on EU goods, according to the aforementioned group of alcohol trade groups.
description: A 15-year dispute over aircraft subsidies leads to 25% tariffs on $7.5 billion in EU products
